Authors:
Svante Martinsson, Steven V. Fend, Mårten J. Klinth,
Patrick Martin, Takaaki Torii, Christer Erseus
Title:
Molecular phylogeny leads the way towards a revision of
Haplotaxidae (Annelida: Clitellata)
Keywords:
12S; 16S; 18S; 28S; Bayesian Inference; new family; new
genus; new species; taxonomy; COI
Abstract:
The classification and phylogenetic position of
Haplotaxidae, an enigmatic family of clitellate worms, have long been
discussed. We estimate the phylogeny for Clitellata as a whole, using a
taxon sample adhering to current definition of Haplotaxidae and
including species attributable to Haplotaxis, plus a representation of
other clitellates. Sequences of five markers, in total 4087 bp, were
analysed by Bayesian Inference. A well-supported tree shows that
Haplotaxidae is polyphyletic, consisting of at least five separate
clades scattered among other clitellate lineages. We redefine
Haplotaxidae s. str. to only include Haplotaxis, and describe
Pelodrilidae Martinsson et al. fam. n. for Pelodrilus, Hologynus, and
Delaya, and Haplotaxoididae Martinsson et al. fam. n. for Haplotaxoides
Fend gen. n. (with H. decipens Fend sp. n. and H. tehama Fend sp. n.).
Further, we describe Kurenkovia setoensis Fend & Torii sp. n. and
Ohtakiana kakidaensis Fend & Torii gen. et sp. n., both currently
considered incertae sedis. Haplotaxidae and Pelodrilidae seem to belong
to an incompletely resolved group also including lumbriculids, leeches
and earthworms. Moreover, a close relationship between Kurenkovia,
Ohtakiana and the lumbriculid-hirudinean clade (i.e., taxon
Lumbriculata) is strongly supported, whereas Haplotaxoididae seems to
have its roots among the somewhat older, paraphyletic assemblage of
“microdrile” families.
